Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Toward an Understanding of the Indirect Climatic Effect of Organic Aerosol: Quantitative Assessments Using Experimental Characterization and Model Integration
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of this project is to improve the community's understanding of the aerosol indirect (or secondary aerosol) effect through examination of the role of carbonaceous material. Laboratory and field experimental activities will be combined with numerical modeling exercises. A new method for characterizing cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) will be developed that combines size resolved measurements of surface tension, critical supersaturation and chemical composition, which will allow determination of the effects of organic species on CCN properties in near real time. The observations made with the new technique will be incorporated into a numerical module designed to simulate aerosol-cloud interactions which when incorporated into global climate models can be used to assess indirect forcing.

The project will expose undergraduate engineers and scientists to atmospheric research. The PI will expose gifted high school students to atmospheric science with the goal to inspire them to a career in science and engineering. Two Ph.D. students will be given experimental and numerical modeling experiences. There are a number of formal education and outreach programs (e.g. SURE and STEP) at the PI's home institution that will be exploited in this project. Societal benefits are likely with improved understanding of the atmospheric chemical-climate system. The results will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at national and international scientific conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major outcomes: Development and characterization of novel methods for measuring CCN concentrations and CCN activity (Objectives 1,2)

  • Characterization of the the CCN instrument. Comprehensive computational models were developed to predict instrument behavior for real-world conditions, and to explore/quantify limitations and artifacts. The models were instrumental for the study of CCN activation kinetics and for developing breakthroughs CCN measurement techniques (Scanning Flow CCN Analysis).
  • Development of Scanning Mobility CCN Analysis (SMCA), Scanning Flow CCN Analysis (SFCA). These techniques allow high-resolution, rapid measurements of size-resolved CCN activity (SMCA), and, very rapid measurements of CCN spectra. The reduction in measurement timescale accomplished is considerable against priexisting approaches can be more than tenfold.
  • Development of Kohler Theory Analysis (KTA). Using size-resolved measurements of CCN activity and chemical composition combined with Kohler theory, we develop a methodology to estimate the average molar volume of organics in a given sample, as well as deconvolute solute from surface tension effects on CCN activity. The techniques were used to interpret the nature of organics from a wide range of sources, including primary organics from the surface ocean, biomass burning organics, aerosol from urban/remote filters and secondary organic aerosol from aerosol chambers.
  • Development of mixing state analysis (MSA). From size-resolved measurements of CCN activity, we developed a methodology to infer the mixing state (i.e., fraction of non-active CCN) and distribution of hygroscopicity for ambient aerosol as a function of size. This sort of information gives an invaluable insight on the distribution of hygroscopic material in ambient CCN and the microphysical processes responsible for their evolution. The method was used to analyze aerosol in remote and strongly anthropogenically-influenced locations.
  • Development of Threshold Droplet Growth Analysis (TDGA) and other kinetic interpretation methods. From size-resolved measurements of CCN activity, we developed a methodology to infer the mixing state (i.e., fraction of non-active CCN) and distribution of hygroscopicity for ambient aerosol as a function of size. This sort of information gives an invaluable insight on the distribution of hygroscopic material in ambient CCN and the microphysical processes responsible for their evolution. The method was used to analyze aerosol in remote and strongly anthropogenically-influenced locations.

 

Major outcomes: Field deployment and laboratory analysis of field samples (Objective 3)

  • Organics contribute considerably to the CCN activity of aerosols. Excluding their influence can lead to substantial CCN prediction biases, on the order of 50% or more in climate-sensitive regions of the globe (such as the Arctic). Very simple descriptions of the organic hygroscopicity however can be used that corrects most of the CCN prediction bias.
  • The water-soluble fraction is the prime source of bulk aerosol hygroscopicity. In all the ambient samples considered, the hygroscopicity of organic material was found to be proportional to the volume fraction of soluble organics; the proportionality constant was also found to vary very little across samples. Evidence suggests that surface tension variability is compensated by solute effects to yield a quasi-constant proportionality constant.
